content:
I suggest to put more emphasis on the fact that there is only one buy and one sell per day, because the problem seems much, much harder when you don't read that line, like I did just now in a Fastest mode clash.

Managed to win anyway, after eventually giving up the full solution and deciding to see if just solving for the best single trade was enough to pass the tests and lucked out that it was the right answer. :)

I suggest putting it in **bold* in rule 2, or even splitting rule 2 up into more rules because there's a lot of important detail hidden in there. Including about fractions of potatoes, which is important to make the clash simpler too. Fun clash overall though. :)
This contribution hasnâ€™t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

Please confirm this VALIDATOR:


Not a real chance! VALIDATOR

Input:
200.0
5
50.0
100.0
50.0
1.0
2.0

Output:
400

I believe it should be 800, not 400, here's my logic

Day 1 : Price: 50.0    Action: Buy      Balance: $0 / 4Pots
Day 2 : Price: 100.0  Action: Sell      Balance: $400 / 0P
Day 3 : Price: 50.0    Action: None   Balance: $400 / 0P
Day 4 : Price: 1.0      Action: Buy      Balance: $0 / 400P
Day 5 : Price: 2.0      Action: Sell       Balance: $800 / 0P

Please check this.
the part about the fractional number of potatoes is not very clear. Maybe you should explain it a little more
The inputs are float but you never use that. Why don't you just make the inputs integers?
please be more specific with the "rounded to nearest integer" - does it round up, round down, or round off?

Cute puzzle. Seems a bit similar to other puzzles on the platform, but nice as a clash.
Please specify in the description that fractions of potatoes can also be sold. This is where the analogy of potatoes stops working :) 
Also, please make sure your validators are at least a bit different from the tests.

without possibilty to buy/sell many times, it is really similar to
https://www.codingame.com/ide/puzzle/stock-exchange-losses

I'm sure it's pretty obvious he means .5+ up else down since there's no other way to interpret "nearest integer" and balance is always positive unless he explicitly states "Banking Rounding" or anything.
"Only one buy-sell operation is allowed per day"

Point #3
"3. If you don't want to trade today you can skip and amount of money on your account will not change."

Here,
None=Skip

Else, the other test cases would fail as well.

You're still wrong. In this task you are trading during ONE day.
"... you got a task to analyze data for previous day"
"Price of potato changes during the day... "
"... and have a list of potatoes price ticks during the day"

I am not able to understand what is it that you are saying.
So, what would be the actual sequence for that test case? A dry run might help be better understand what is it that you are saying.

aklgupta, the provided list of prices is not list of prices for different days, but list of prices during _one_ day. So you can do one buy-sell operation inside the day, or skip this operation (so no action will be performed)

Oh! I get it now. I don't how I missed it, even after helgui quoting that line.
Thanks.
If it's rounding off, it should say rounding off. You even made a counter-point against your own argument yourself.

Thanks, menger3, I've updated Statement to include fractional number of potatoes. For validators do you mean that they should have different logic? I check the same cases (so names are the same), but numbers are different.

I didn't notice the number changes, as they are very subtle. That's fine
However, seeing dwarfie's comment above, please note that this puzzle is too similar to an existing puzzle.
